raw_comment:
When observing the graph of college admissions, you can see that kids with a legacy boost are at a much more significant advantage compared to kids who do not have a legacy. 
We can also see that even kids with the highest income level are at an enormous disadvantage compared to kids with a higher income and a legacy boost. 
This is disheartening because as a high achieving and striving student who wants to attend an Ivy League just because I don't have a legacy, I am already behind before applying. It also makes me even more upset for the students already at an economic disadvantage because even if they are much better academically than another student with a legacy, the lesser student is more likely to be accepted because of the school's predisposed preference.
ace_sentences: A person can observe a graph of college admissions.
The graph shows kids with a legacy boost.
The graph shows kids without a legacy boost.
Kids with a legacy boost have a more significant advantage than kids without a legacy boost.
The graph shows kids with the highest income level.
The graph shows kids with a higher income and a legacy boost.
Kids with the highest income level have an enormous disadvantage compared to kids with a higher income and a legacy boost.
I want to attend an Ivy League university.
I do not have a legacy.
Because I do not have a legacy, I am already behind before I apply.
This situation makes me more upset for students at an economic disadvantage.
Some students at an economic disadvantage are much better academically than another student with a legacy.
A school has a predisposed preference for a student with a legacy.
Because of this preference, the lesser student is more likely to be accepted.
